description: {"blocks":[{"key":"d5boi","text":"This protocol presents the first detailed step-by-step pipeline for the 3D scanning and post processing of large batches of lithic artefacts using a micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) scanner (i.e., a Phoenix v-tome-x S model by General Electronics MCC, Boston MA) and an Artec Space Spider scanner (Artec Inc., Luxembourg). This protocol was used to scan and analyze ca. 700 lithic artefacts from the Protoaurignacian layers at Fumane Cave in north-eastern Italy (Falcucci et al., in preparation).","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tk32","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brbde","text":"For this study several costly scanners and proprietary software packages were employed. Although it is not easy to find a low-budget alternative for the scanners, it is possible to use free and open-source software programs, such as 3D-Slicer (https://www.slicer.org/) or MorphoDig (https://morphomuseum.com/morphodig), to process CT data as well as MeshLab (Cignoni et al. 2008) to interact with the 3D models in general. However, if alternative software is used, the steps and their order described in this protocol might diverge significantly.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avuqh","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4rdrv","text":"A cost-effective alternative to create 3D models is digital photogrammetry using commercial cameras and freely available software like Meshroom (https://alicevision.org). Although photogrammetry is an affordable technique to create accurate 3D models of objects, this method might not be useful when scanning large batches of artefacts, as it will require a lot of computation time and processing capacity. Likewise, it could be difficult to generate accurate 3D models of very small and/or detailed tool shapes using 3D surface scanners because stone tools are often much smaller than the recommended minimum field of view. Similarly, the resolution of conventional medical CT scanners might not be sufficient to capture minor details of stone tools, such as the outline or dorsal scars. Thus, high-resolution micro-CT technology is the only reliable way to accurately capture the overall morphology of small stone tools. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8letf","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9to86","text":"This protocol aims at providing the first detailed procedure dedicated to the scanning of small lithic implements for further three-dimensional analysis. Note that some of the steps must be repeated at different working stages throughout this protocol. In cases where a task must be done in the exact same way as described in a previous step, a reference to that step is provided. When slight changes were made, the step was modified and reported entirely. This protocol contains a few red and green colours (e.g., arrows or within-program colours) which might be perceived differently by people with dyschromatopsia. However, the display of these colours has been kept to a minimum.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31iav","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82am6","text":"We recommend the reader to go over the entire protocol carefully, even if only some specific parts are required. A few points are in fact interdependent, and some of them must be applied simultaneously.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"402vb","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ceibe","text":"Content:","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7kqn","text":"Part 1 – Styrofoam preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqard","text":"Part 2 – Micro-CT scanning","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7r5c4","text":"Part 3 – 3D model extraction of CT scanned stone artifacts using Avizo","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7nfn9","text":"Part 4 – Cropping extracted surface model to separate Face A and B in Artec Studio","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3p0pk","text":"Part 5 – Cropping Face A to separate the lines in Artec Studio","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79ci6","text":"Part 6 – Cropping each stone artefact from the lines in Artec Studio","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ftm5p","text":"Part 7 – Virtually control measurements in MeshLab","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv4fq","text":"Part 8 – Artec scanning of larger artifacts","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fdug","text":"Part 9 – Export meshes as non-binary ply models for successive analysis in geomorph","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6},{"style":"italic","offset":75,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fpqn","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"13h7a","text":"Three-dimensional example (in ply format) of the effectivity of the StyroStone Protocol:","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":88},{"style":"italic","offset":30,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"834c7","text":"You can download an example of one Styrofoam line in 3D obtained using our protocol to appreciate the result that can be achieved. We have selected a line where objects are characterized by different metric and morphological attributes. Notice the retouching well visible in the last five smaller artifacts (counting from the left when artifact are oriented with the dorsal face in front of the observer and the butt down), as well as the platforms and bulbs of all artifacts. For more information and examples, feel free to contact us!","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8g54q","text":"  ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"","data":{"forceSelection":true,"guid":"FD23CFA037DF11EC8942FB1868E0866D","id":182020,"nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Example.ply","placeholder":"","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/ft2ebnk3f.ply"}}}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f0qs4","text":"Note: Depending on the number of lithics that need to be scanned, this section might take several hours.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"97hu6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dvv3","text":"Select a blank Styrofoam body (or similar material) to hold the artefacts. It should be thick enough to carve holes on both sides (Face A and Face B).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"1915o","text":"Identify the scanning size limitations of the micro-CT scanner. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"445fq","text":"Cut the Styrofoam body into a rectangle according to the dimensions determined in Step 2. Our dimensions: 25 cm (height) x 22 cm (width) x 5 cm (thickness). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":82,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"618g4","text":"To increase the stability, you might add an additional Styrofoam support as base of ca. 2 cm height and a width of a few cm wider than the area of contact between the two parts (our total Styrofoam body height was 27 cm). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f18vj","text":"Glue the two Styrofoam pieces together with Polyvinyl acetate (white glue).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fp5nr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e0d84","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ltel","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6hbke","text":"Draw guiding or separation lines with a dark marker on both sides (Face A and B) of the Styrofoam body depending on the size and number of artefacts that need to be scanned – these will determine the rows or lines in which the artefacts will be placed one after another.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f4eg7","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8tq2","text":"The row separation will help to keep the artefacts in the same orientation and will simplify the subsequent 3D model extraction after the CT-scanning process. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"3kpud","text":"Draw a mark (e.g., a dot or “A”) on the first side of the Styrofoam (Face A), which will later facilitate the correct identification of the artefacts.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c2cmj","text":"Carve holes along rows into the Styrofoam with a box cutter that are roughly the same dimensions of the artefacts. They should be secure enough to ensure a stable positioning and protect the artefacts from moving during the CT-scanning process. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4mqak","text":"Insert the artefact directly into its hole and immediately document its position in the Styrofoam as described in Step 6.2 (Fig. 1).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":114,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bp9d9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e8f91","text":"On Face A, place the first artefact on the left most position of the first row and continue in this line towards the right until the line is fully occupied. Then continue with the second row below, again starting at the left side until Face A is completed. Continue with Face B in the same way. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5v881","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bg6hb","text":"Insert lithics following the best-suited criteria depending on how the lithic assemblages are curated (e.g., stratigraphic units, raw materials, ID numbers) or according to the size variation of the artefacts if necessary.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4b2qb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8sgeh","text":"Always use the same orientation of the artefacts, i.e., dorsal face facing upwards and proximal side at the bottom. By placing the longest axis of the specimen vertically, the object thickness between the source and the detector remains limited during the scanning process, requiring less x-ray penetration power and thus reducing energy costs. Moreover, during the later post-processing step, such an orientation will enable easier identification and virtual separation among 3D scans of lithics when compared with the reference list of artefacts (Step 6.2) and reference photographs of the Styrofoam body (Step 7.1 and 7.2).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":549,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":608,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"14nqj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3kqu7","text":"In our case, we scanned ca. 700 lithics with the CT-scanner using 4 Styrofoam bodies each with two faces (A and B) for a total of 8 faces. Each face consisted of ca. 4 to 8 lines and each line contained ca. 10 to 20 artefacts (total of ca. 60 to 120 artefacts per face).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"59e2a","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"51e6l","text":"   ","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f2qi0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"8499D900326A11EC849569C706EE0BE9","height":443.96363636363566,"id":182849,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"46fs6","text":"Fig. 1: Overview of a completely filled Styrofoam body (Face A).","type":"align-left"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Figure_1.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fuudbnk3f.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fuubbnk3f.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fuucbnk3f.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/fuuabnk3f.webp","width":580}}}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8r3nf","text":"Document the exact position of each artefact in a spreadsheet (e.g., MS Excel) directly after it is inserted into its Styrofoam hole.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"egtfe","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eecs8","text":"Clearly indicate the Styrofoam side, row, and at which numeric position the artefacts are located. For simplicity reasons you might use a coded identification key.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d6t96","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pek6","text":"Example: An artefact with the location code S1-FA-L2.5 would be inserted into first Styrofoam body (S1; only in cases where several bodies must be used to scan large amounts of lithics) Face A (FA, first Styrofoam side) in the second row from the top to the bottom (L2) and at the fifth position from the left to the right (.5) in this row.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":44,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":47,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":100,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":194,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":266,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":324,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":100,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":194,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":266,"length":2},{"style":"italic","offset":324,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37tkh","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"66uif","text":"Keeping track of the positions is extremely important and will not only ensure the fast and correct labelling of the right artefact ID with the 3D models, but also ensure the artefacts are safely returned to their find bags. Therefore, you might use a handwritten list as backup. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"auhes","text":"Take reference pictures.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"121oa","text":"After Face A and B are filled, take reference pictures of both faces.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5ndtg","text":"Take a picture of the first artefact of the first row of each face. This will serve as a reference to orient the 3D model of the entire face, making the later identification of the artefacts’ order much easier.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 1 - Styrofoam preparation

steps.section: Part 2 - Micro-CT scanning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9au1s","text":"The turning base should be positioned as far as possible from the source to increase the field of view and, therefore, the number of lithics that can be scanned at one time. Note that with greater distance from the source, the resolution decreases. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9vj3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 2 - Micro-CT scanning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4obtr","text":"Set up the machine according to the best scanning parameters – usually done by the scanning technician.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3rkg3","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mfgp","text":"For scanning multiple specimens at the same time, it is advisable to use the “multiscans” option, which enables the device to scan longer targets within the same scanning session. In particular, using the scanner’s associated computer device and software (e.g., Phoenix Datos-X software; General Electronics MCC), the scanning technician virtually separates the target into different layers (by Styrofoam height) to be scanned individually (per layer/scan), which are then automatically merged before model reconstruction. It must be highlighted that the use of this option might produce visual artefacts in the resulting 3D models, appearing as lines at the borders in between the layered scans (i.e., “merging lines”). To ensure that these lines will not affect stone tool morphology, the technician should make sure that the selected upper and lower borderlines of each layer/scan do not intersect any stone tools.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9gd5l","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9mjm","text":"The resolution used across our scans was ca. 140 microns. Resolution largely depends on the distance between the source and the target/object. Even though the utilized micro-CT scanner is technically capable of producing models with much greater resolution, our experiments showed that 140 microns was a good balance, allowing us to scan a large number of artefacts at once, while avoiding distinguishable inaccuracies in the resulting 3D surface form (size and shape) of the blades and bladelets.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 2 - Micro-CT scanning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"8cgbd","text":"Start scanning process. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 2 - Micro-CT scanning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"jtb","text":"After the scanning process is completed, save the scans onto a hard disk. Make sure to save the scanning metadata (e.g., as .pcr file), including all scanning parameters, which are required to open and scale the CT scans (e.g., in Avizo). Important scanning parameters to successfully load the CT data into Avizo Lite are the resolution (Voxel size), volume dimensions (x, y, z), and image data type (e.g., 16 bit).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 2 - Micro-CT scanning
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"clsfm","text":"Visualize the overall scanning result to check for obvious errors. This can be done by reconstructing the CT data and exporting the file as an image stack, e.g., as .tiff files or .vol files, which can be opened in Avizo Lite. Reconstruction of the CT data can be performed, visualized, and exported using software like Phoenix Datos-X. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Part 7 – Virtually control measurements in MeshLab
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7n9gf","text":"Note: It might be useful to take control measurements for time to time, e.g., of the first and last artefact in a line and a few random artefacts elsewhere. This helps to check whether the line is exactly positioned and whether any artefacts were accidently skipped.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":5}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kpcv","text":" ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"frp6e","text":"If all artefacts are measured, errors in the database could also be cross-checked. However, with larger sample sizes, this may take a lot of time. Linear measurements (e.g., maximum length of the artefact) can easily be taken in MeshLab (Cignoni et al. 2008) then compared with physically measured variables in the main database. For any subsequent intra- or interobserver error and methodological evaluations, it might be useful to store the virtual control measurements in an extra column of the main database. To save time, this task can easily be combined with the export of the models to non-binary ply. files if necessary for subsequent analysis in the R package geomorph  (see below).","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":669,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"63odo","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9uc0v","text":"Open MeshLab.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dqmhp","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9hrvn","text":"To manually align sub-scans, use the options to place matching pairs between each scan. The software will detect the right point itself.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
